title: 108_hr2887
content: The "Riayan Tejeda Memorial Act of 2003" requires naturalization through service in combat zones during Operation Iraqi Freedom. Aliens who served honorably in combat zones during Operation Iraqi Freedom can be naturalized without following the usual requirements under the Immigration and Nationality Act. They must file an application and take the oath as specified by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Aliens who served honorably in combat zones during Operation Iraqi Freedom can be naturalized without usual requirements under the Immigration and Nationality Act. No fees can be charged for filing an application for naturalization or for the issuance of a certificate of naturalization. The Secretaries of Homeland Security, State, and Defense must ensure that all processes related to naturalization for aliens who served in combat zones during Operation Iraqi Freedom are available at US embassies, consulates, and military installations overseas. Extension of posthumous benefits to surviving spouses, children, and parents. Extension of posthumous benefits to surviving spouses, children, and parents. Treatment as Immediate Relatives for spouses of deceased citizens who served in the military in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom. The text discusses the eligibility of surviving spouses and children of deceased citizens who served in the military for posthumous benefits. Spouses can remain immediate relatives if they file a petition within 2 years of the citizen's death and until they remarry. Children of deceased citizens who served in the military are also eligible for benefits. If a surviving spouse or child of a deceased citizen who served in the military in a combat zone designated in connection with Operation Iraqi Freedom files a petition within 2 years of the citizen's death, they can remain immediate relatives for immigration purposes. Parents of a deceased citizen who served in the military in a designated combat zone can file a petition with the Secretary of Homeland Security for immigration classification under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Parents of a deceased citizen who served in a combat zone related to Operation Iraqi Freedom can file a petition with the Secretary of Homeland Security within 2 years of the citizen's death to remain an immediate relative under the Immigration and Nationality Act. For adjustment of status under the Immigration and Nationality Act, a citizen described in a petition does not need to be 21 years old for a parent to benefit. This exception applies to surviving spouses, children, and parents of deceased citizens who served in a combat zone related to Operation Iraqi Freedom. Under section 245 of the Immigration and Nationality Act, certain aliens who were spouses, children, or parents of military personnel who died in a combat zone related to Operation Iraqi Freedom may have their adjustment of status applications adjudicated even after the death of the military member. Posthumous citizenship was granted under section 329A of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Spouses and children of lawful permanent resident aliens can be considered valid petitioners for immediate relative status under certain conditions. Under section 201(b)(2)(A)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1151(b)(2)(A)(i)), alien spouses or children are eligible for deferred action, advance parole, and work authorization. They can file a petition with the Secretary of Homeland Security for classification under the same Act. Alien spouses or children who served honorably in specified military branches in a combat zone related to Operation Iraqi Freedom can file a petition for family-sponsored immigrant classification with the Secretary of Homeland Security within 2 years. They are eligible for deferred action, advance parole, and work authorization. Parents of lawful permanent resident aliens can file a petition for classification under the Immigration and Nationality Act within 2 years if their child died as a result of injury or disease incurred during Operation Iraqi Freedom and was granted posthumous citizenship. They are eligible for deferred action, advance parole, and work authorization. An alien described in this paragraph served honorably in the military, died as a result of service-related injury or disease, and was granted posthumous citizenship. They are eligible for adjustment of status in the United States. An alien in the United States can apply for adjustment of status to permanent residence if they are the beneficiary of a petition under certain subsections. Certain grounds of inadmissibility do not apply to aliens accorded immigration benefits under this section. Prohibition on benefits to survivors does not apply to relatives of a person granted posthumous citizenship. Any surviving spouse, child, or parent of a U.S. citizen who dies during honorable service in specified military branches in a combat zone related to Operation Iraqi Freedom can be naturalized. No prior residence requirement applies. No prior residence or physical presence in the United States is required for naturalization under the Nationality Act. Priority for naturalization applications is given to applications filed under section 2 of the Act and applications for naturalization of family members of military personnel who have served in designated combat zones.
